case_name: Kalwa Devadattam, Kalwa Devarayulu and Kalwa Nandi Sankarappa v. Union of India

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 641 and 642 of 1961 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCivil Appeals Nos. 641 and 642 of 1961. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated April 11, 1957, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in A.S. Nos. 95 and 520 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decree dated April 11, 1957, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in A.S. Nos. 95 and 520 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated April 11, 1957, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in A.S. Nos. 95 and 520 of 1952. V. Viswanatha sastri, P.V. Chalapati Rau, S.N. Andley, and Rameshwar Nath, for the appellants.

facts.text: Nagappa son of Pullanna resident of Nandyal carried on business in yarn, drugs and forward contracts.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH J.--Nagappa son of Pullanna resident Nandyal carried on business in yarn, drugs and forward companytracts. He acquired in that business a companysiderable estate which was treated by him as property of the joint family of himself and his sons.

facts.text: Nagappa acquired considerable estate treated as property of the joint family of himself and his sons.

anchor.surface_text: He acquired in that business a companysiderable estate which was treated by him as property of the joint family of himself and his sons. Nagappa and his sons were assessed by the Incometax authorities to pay income-tax and supper-tax in the status of a Hindu undivided family as set out in the following table --

facts.text: Nagappa and his sons assessed as Hindu undivided family for 1944-45: income-tax and super-tax Rs. 51,116-7-0 on 25-2-48, year ending 24-3-44.

anchor.surface_text: Nagappa and his sons were assessed by the Incometax authorities to pay income-tax and supper-tax in the status of a Hindu undivided family as set out in the following table -- Year of Year of Date of Income-tax and account assess- order. super-tax ending ment. assessed. ------------- -------- ------- --------------- 24-3-44 1944-45 25-2-48 Rs. 51,116-7-0

facts.text: Assessments for 1945-46: Rs. 21,452-1-0 on 25-2-48, year ending 14-3-45.

anchor.surface_text: 14-3-45 1945-46 25-2-48 Rs. 21,452-1-0 2-4-46 1946-47 31-3-48 Rs. 21,012-13-0 Besides this amount of income-tax and supertax he was assessed to pay penalty and excess profits tax aggregating to Rs. 26,602/-

facts.text: Total tax due for 1944-45, 1945-46, 1946-47 aggregated to Rs. 1,23,233/5/- including penalty and excess profits tax Rs. 26,602/-

anchor.surface_text: Besides this amount of income-tax and supertax he was assessed to pay penalty and excess profits tax aggregating to Rs. 26,602/-. The total amount of tax due for the three years of assessment 1944-45, 1945-46 and 1946-47 aggregated to Rs. 1,23,233/5/-

facts.text: Nagappa did not pay the tax.

anchor.surface_text: . Nagappa did number pay the tax. The revenue authorities of the Province of Madras, at the instance of the Income-tax Department attached 51 items of immovable property as belonging to the joint family of Nagappa and his sons and put up the same for sale under the Madras Revenue Recovery Act II of 1864.

facts.text: Revenue authorities attached 51 items of immovable property belonging to joint family and sold 38 items.

anchor.surface_text: The revenue authorities of the Province of Madras, at the instance of the Income-tax Department attached 51 items of immovable property as belonging to the joint family of Nagappa and his sons and put up the same for sale under the Madras Revenue Recovery Act II of 1864. Out of these 38 items were sold and were purchased by certain persons.

facts.text: Kalwa Devadattam, Kalwa Devarayulu and Kalwa Nandi Sankarappa, sons of Nagappa, through mother as next friend, commenced suit No. 52 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Kalwa Devadattam, Kalwa Devarayulu and Kalwa Nandi Sankarappa  sons of Nagappa  hereinafter called companylectively the plaintiffs--through their mother acting as their next friend companymenced suit No. 52 of 1950 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Kurnool,

facts.text: Plaintiffs claimed assessments for 1944-45 to 1946-47 unenforceable against 51 items, sale void; items 46-51 acquired from maternal grandmother Seshamma; other items allotted on partition before assessment.

anchor.surface_text: claiming a decree declaring that the assessment orders made by the Income-tax officer, Kurnool, for the years 1944-45, 1945-46 and 1946-47 were unenforceable against 51 items of property of the plaintiffs described in the schedule and sale of their property by the revenue authorities was without jurisdiction, void and illegal,

facts.text: Deed of partition dated March 14, 1947 between Nagappa and plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: This decree was soon followed by the execution of the deed of partition,dated March 14, 1947, between Nagappa and the plaintiffs, by which the joint family estate valued approximately at Rs. 1,25,000/- was divided into four shares.

facts.text: Kumaji Sare Mal filed suit No. 7 of 1944 against Nagappa, decreed by High Court on March 5, 1947 for Rs. 10,000/- with interest.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which gave rise to that suit are these Kumaji Sare Mal filed suit No. 7 of 1944 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Anantpur, against Nagappa for a decree for Rs. 10,022-10-6 due at the foot of certain transactions in yarn. This suit was dismissed by the Trial Court on the ground that the companytracts for the supply of yarn were wagering companytracts, but in Appeal No. 174 of 1945 the High Court of Madras decreed the suit on March 5, 1947 holding that the companytracts giving rise to the liability though speculative were number of a wagering Character.

facts.text: Trial Court held partition on March 14, 1947 real and operative, items 46-51 not joint family property.

anchor.surface_text: The Court further held that items 46 to 51 were number proved by the defendants to be the joint family property of the plaintiffs and Nagappa. In suit No. 54 of 1949 the learned Judge held following Schwebo K.S.R.M. Firm through Partner Govindan, alias Ramanathan Chettiar v. Subbiah alias Shanmugham Chettiar  1 , that after a partition between the members of the joint Hindu family the sons share in the joint family property cannot be proceeded against in execution so as to enforce the pious obligation of the sons to satisfy their fathers debts under a decree passed against the father alone.

facts.text: High Court held partition sham, items 46-51 purchased with joint family funds.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Andhra Pradesh to which the appeals stood transferred for hearing under the States Reorganisation Act 1956 held agreeing with the Trial Court that a suit to set aside the assessment of income-tax was number maintainable against the Union, and that in any event in the absence of an order under s. 25A I  of the Indian Income-tax Act, recording a partition, the Income-tax authorities were bound to assess tax on the Hindu undivided family as if that status companytinued.

facts.text: Items 46 to 51 purchased by sale deed Ext. A-230 dated March 15, 1944 for Rs. 23,500/- in names of two plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: About the title of the plaintiffs to items 46 to 51 in the schedule annexed to the plaint, the High Court disagreed with the Trial Court. These properties were purchased in the names of two of the three plaintiffs by the sale deed Ext. A-230 dated March 15, 1944. The companysideration of the sale deed was Rs. 23,500/-of which Rs. 5,019/-had been paid in advance in four instalments before March 15, 1944,

facts.text: Supreme Court held items 46-51 purchased with joint family funds.

anchor.surface_text: It must therefore be held that the Courts below were right in holding that the plaintiffs have failed to establish that the properties companyveyed by the sale-deed were purchased with the funds supplied by Seshamma. It is companymon ground that the plaintiffs had numberother source of income.

facts.text: Nagappa made statement to ITO on January 19, 1948 about partition ten months back.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case numberorder under S. 25A  1  was recorded. It is true, that Nagappa had made before the Income-tax Officer on January 19, 1948 the following statement I am at present living singly. My sons divided from me about ten months back. There is a document to this effect.

facts.text: Supreme Court held partition deed dated March 14, 1947 was sham and not intended to be operative.

anchor.surface_text: for we are definitely of the that partition was a sham transaction which was number intended to be operative. On March 14, 1947 the deed of partition was executed and registered. The object of this partition it is alleged was to protect the interest of his minor sons against their father who was acting to the detriment of his sons and was number even living with the family.

facts.text: Nagappa and family living together even after partition.

anchor.surface_text: Witness Singari Seshanna D.W.I. has deposed that Nagappa, his wife and children were living together in the family house even at the date of the suit and that Nagappa was companylecting rents from all the houses.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 641 of 1961 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 641 of 1961 must therefore fail. We may number deal with the questions which fall to be determined in Civil Appeal No. 642 of 1961-one of the questions being companymon in Appeals Nos. 641 and 642 of 1961.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 642 of 1961 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Appeal No. 642 of 1961 must therefore also fail.

issues.text: Whether the suit filed by the plaintiffs against the Union of India challenging the income-tax assessments is maintainable in a civil court?

anchor.surface_text: The suit filed by the plaintiffs against the Union must therefore fail on three independent grounds, each of which is sufficient to non-suit them. The suit which was in substance one for setting aside an assessment was in law not maintainable because of S. 67 of the Indian Income-tax Act

issues.text: Whether, in the absence of an order under s. 25A(1) recording partition, the Hindu undivided family is deemed to continue undivided for tax purposes under s. 25A(3)?

anchor.surface_text: under s. 25A 1 of the Indian Income-tax Act, the Income-tax Officer was bound to assess the undivided family even after partition on the footing that the family still continued to be joint. ... by virtue of sub-s. 3 the family shall be deemed, for the purposes of the Act, to continue to remain a Hindu undivided family.

issues.text: Whether the partition by the deed dated March 14, 1947 between Nagappa and his sons the plaintiffs was a sham transaction?

anchor.surface_text: We will reserve for separate consideration the common question which arose in these two appeals, namely, whether the partition by the deed dated March 14, 1947 between Nagappa and his sons the plaintiffs was a sham transaction.

issues.text: Whether income-tax liability arises on the accrual of income before the assessment orders and prior to the alleged partition?

anchor.surface_text: Under the Indian Income Tax Act liability to pay income.tax arises on the accrual of the income, and not from the computation made by the Taxing authorities in the course of assessment proceedings it arises at a point of time not later than the close of the year of account.

issues.text: Whether items 46 to 51 were purchased with joint family funds or separate funds provided by Seshamma?

anchor.surface_text: The properties having been purchased in the names of the two plaintiffs the burden prima facie lay upon the Taxing authorities to establish that the sale deed was taken for and on behalf of the joint family

issues.text: Whether the creditor can enforce the pious obligation of the sons in execution of the decree against the father post-partition, or must file a separate suit?

anchor.surface_text: On the question as to the proper procedure for enforcement of the liability of a Hindu son to discharge the debts of his father which are not avyavaharika, where since the passing of the decree on the debt against the father there has been a partition between the father and son,

issues.text: Whether the debt due to Kumaji Sare Mal was avyavaharika, rendering the sons not liable?

anchor.surface_text: claiming that the debt incurred by Nagappa being avyavaharika, the plaintiffs were not liable to satisfy the debt, and that the firm of Kumaji Sare Mal was incompetent to bring to sale in execution of the decree

The plaintiffs then filed suit No. 54 of 1949 for a decree setting aside the summary order passed in the execution proceeding, claiming that the debt incurred by Nagappa being avyavaharika, the plaintiffs were number liable to satisfy the debt, and that the firm of Kumaji Sare Mal was incompetent to bring to sale in execution of the decree obtained against Nagappa in his individual capacity, the interest of the plaintiffs in the joint family property after the joint family status was severed and the properties of the family were partitioned.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge held that the properties items 1 to 45 belonged in the relevant years of assessment to the joint family of Nagappa and his sons, and in the absence of an order recording partition under s. 25A 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, the Income-tax Officer was bound to assess the undivided family even after partition on the footing that the family still continued to be joint. He further held that by virtue of s. 67 of the Indian Income-tax Act, number action questioning the assessment could be entertained by the Courts, and that there was number irregularity in the proceedings for sale.

The Court further held that items 46 to 51 were number proved by the defendants to be the joint family property of the plaintiffs and Nagappa.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Andhra Pradesh to which the appeals stood transferred for hearing under the States Reorganisation Act 1956 held agreeing with the Trial Court that a suit to set aside the assessment of income-tax was number maintainable against the Union, and that in any event in the absence of an order under s. 25A I  of the Indian Income-tax Act, recording a partition, the Income-tax authorities were bound to assess tax on the Hindu undivided family as if that status continued. The High Court also held that the partition set up by the plaintiffs was a transaction which was nominal and sham,

arguments.claim: Income-tax liability arises on accrual of income (end of account year), before partition and assessments.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Indian Income Tax Act liability to pay income.tax arises on the accrual of the income, and number from the computation made by the Taxing authorities in the course of assessment proceedings it arises at a point of time number later than the close of the year of account.

arguments.claim: Even if partition real, suit fails: liability pre-partition; s.25A deems undivided without order; members jointly/severally liable.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 25A of the Income-tax Act, if at the date when the liability to pay tax arose there was in. existence a joint family which has subsequently disrupted, the tax will still be assessed on the Joint family. The machinery for recovery of the tax however. differs according as an order recording partition is.made or number made.

arguments.claim: No s.25A(1) order recorded despite Nagappa's statement; s.25A(3) deems family undivided.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case number order under S. 25A 1  was recorded. It is true, that Nagappa had made before the Income-tax Officer on January 19, 1948 the following statement I am at present living singly. My sons divided from me about ten months back.

arguments.claim: Remedy against assessment error is statutory appeal under s.30, not civil suit; s.67 bars suit.

anchor.surface_text: their remedy was to take an appropriate appeal under S. 30 of the Indian Income-tax Act and number a suit challenging the assessment. The method of assessment and the procedure to be followed in that behalf are statutory, and any error or irregularity in the assessment may be rectified in the manner provided by the statute alone, for S. 67 of the Indian Income-tax Act bars a suit in any Civil Court to set aside or modify any assessment made under the Act.

arguments.claim: Burden on taxing authorities to prove joint family purchase, but decide on evidence led, not abstract onus.

anchor.surface_text: The properties having been purchased in the names of the two plaintiffs the burden prima facie lay upon the Taxing authorities to establish that the sale deed was taken for and on behalf of the joint family

arguments.claim: Plaintiffs failed to prove items 46-51 bought with Seshamma's funds; evidence discrepant/unreliable; joint family funds inferred.

anchor.surface_text: Evidence was led by both the sides to support their respective versions. The Trial Court held that the plaintiffs case that their grandmother Seshamma provided the consideration was number proved, but there was also number evidence to show that the consideration was provided by the joint family, and as the burden of proof lay upon the Union, their case must fail.

arguments.claim: Partition deed March 14, 1947 sham/not operative: timing suspicious, continued joint management/living, inadequate shares.

anchor.surface_text: for we are definitely of the that partition was a sham transaction which was number intended to be operative. On March 14, 1947 the deed of partition was executed and registered. The object of this partition it is alleged was to protect the interest of his minor sons against their father who was acting to the detriment of his sons and was number even living with the family.

arguments.claim: Post-partition enforcement of pious obligation: separate suit needed or execution possible? (discusses precedents, but not decided as partition sham).

anchor.surface_text: On the question as to the proper procedure for enforcement of the liability of a Hindu son to discharge the debts of his father which are number avyavaharika, where since the passing of the decree on the debt against the father there has been a partition between the father and son,

arguments.claim: Deed of partition executed March 14, 1947 real and operative despite intent to defeat creditors.

anchor.surface_text: This decree was soon followed by the execution of the deed of partition,dated March 14, 1947, between Nagappa and the plaintiffs, by which the joint family estate valued approximately at Rs. 1,25,000/- was divided into four shares.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ded to state The guardian to these minor children is my wife. I divided my family properties between myself and my children. The properties belonged t

arguments.claim: Kumaji debt not avyavaharika; can execute post-partition by impleading sons (alternative to sham).

court_response_anchor.surface_text: decree, and it was number necessary for them to file a separate suit. On the question as to the proper procedure for enforcement of the liability of a

holdings.text: The suit which was in substance one for setting aside an assessment was in law not maintainable because of S. 67 of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The suit filed by the plaintiffs against the Union must therefore fail on three independent grounds, each of which is sufficient to non-suit them. The suit which was in substance one for setting aside an assessment was in law not maintainable because of S. 67 of the Indian Income-tax Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.67 expressly bars civil suits to set aside or modify tax assessments; statutory appeal under s.30 is exclusive remedy.

holdings.text: Under the Indian Income Tax Act liability to pay income-tax arises on the accrual of the income, and not from the computation made by the Taxing authorities in the course of assessment proceedings; it arises at a point of time not later than the close of the year of account.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Indian Income Tax Act liability to pay income.tax arises on the accrual of the income, and number from the computation made by the Taxing authorities in the course of assessment proceedings it arises at a point of time number later than the close of the year of account.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability vests by charging section no later than end of previous year, per Privy Council in Wallace Brothers; partition post-accrual irrelevant.

holdings.text: In the absence of an order under s.25A(1), by virtue of s.25A(3) the family shall be deemed, for the purposes of the Act, to continue to remain a Hindu undivided family; members jointly and severally liable.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case numberorder under S. 25A 1 was recorded. ... by virtue of sub-s. 3 the family shall be deemed, for the purposes of the Act, to continue to remain a Hindu undivided family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No inquiry or order recorded despite Nagappa's statement; s.25A(3) deeming provision applies; machinery for post-partition recovery affirmed per Privy Council analysis.

holdings.text: The properties items 46 to 51 were purchased with joint family funds and belong to the joint family, liable for tax.

anchor.surface_text: It must therefore be held that the Courts below were right in holding that the plaintiffs have failed to establish that the properties conveyed by the sale-deed were purchased with the funds supplied by Seshamma.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiffs' evidence on Seshamma unreliable/discrepant; Nagappa paid consideration from business profits; attachment before judgment context supports joint funds inference.

holdings.text: The partition by the deed dated March 14, 1947 was a sham transaction which was not intended to be operative.

anchor.surface_text: for we are definitely of the that partition was a sham transaction which was number intended to be operative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstances: timing post-decree, unequal real shares, continued joint living/management by Nagappa, inadequate allotment to father, no genuine family rift.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether post-partition enforcement of pious obligation requires separate suit or allows execution by impleading son.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think it necessary to express our opinion on the question whether the remedy of the creditor is to file a separate suit...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue obiter as partition held sham; discusses conflicting High Court views but declines to resolve.

holdings.text: The debt to Kumaji Sare Mal was not avyavaharika; speculative contracts but not wagering.

anchor.surface_text: This suit was dismissed by the Trial Court on the ground that the contracts for the supply of yarn were wagering contracts, but in Appeal No. 174 of 1945 the High Court of Madras decreed the suit on March 5, 1947 holding that the contracts giving rise to the liability though speculative were not of a wagering Character.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court decree affirmed; contracts speculative not wagering, hence enforceable against sons under pious obligation.

precedents.citation: Schwebo K.S.R.M. Firm through Partner Govindan, alias Ramanathan Chettiar v. Subbiah alias Shanmugham Chettiar 1

anchor.surface_text: Schwebo K.S.R.M. Firm through Partner Govindan, alias Ramanathan Chettiar v. Subbiah alias Shanmugham Chettiar 1 , that after a partition between the members of the joint Hindu family the sons share in the joint family property cannot be proceeded against in execution so as to enforce the pious obligation of the sons to satisfy their fathers debts under a decree passed against the father alone.

precedents.case_name: Schwebo K.S.R.M. Firm v. Subbiah alias Shanmugham Chettiar
precedents.cited_proposition: after a partition between the members of the joint Hindu family the sons share in the joint family property cannot be proceeded against in execution so as to enforce the pious obligation of the sons to satisfy their fathers debts under a decree passed against the father alone

precedents.citation: Wallace Brothers and Co, Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City and Bombay Suburban District 1 1948 L.R. 75 I.A 86.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in Wallace Brothers and Co, Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City and Bombay Suburban District 1 The general nature of the charging section is clear. First, the charge for tax at the rate fixed for the year of assessment is a charge in respect of the income of the previous year, number a charge in respect of the income of the year of assessment as measured by the income of the previous year.

precedents.case_name: Wallace Brothers and Co, Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: liability to tax arises by virtue of the charging section alone, and it arises number later than the close of the previous year though quantification of the amount payable is postponed
precedents.cited_holding: The general nature of the charging section is clear. First, the charge for tax at the rate fixed for the year of assessment is a charge in respect of the income of the previous year... But the liability to tax arises by virtue of the charging section alone, and it arises number later than the close of the previous year though quantification of the amount payable is postponed.

precedents.citation: Sardar Bahadur Sir Sunder Singh Majithia v. Commissioner of Income-tax, United and Central Provinces 1 1942 L. R, 69 I. A. 119

anchor.surface_text: The judicial Committee of Privy Council in Sardar Bahadur Sir Sunder Singh Majithia v. Commissioner of Income-tax, United and Central Provinces 1 , analysed the scheme of S. 25A as follows - Section 25A is directed to the difficulty which arose when an undivided family had received income in the year of account but was numberlonger in existence as such at the time of assessment.

precedents.case_name: Sardar Bahadur Sir Sunder Singh Majithia v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 25A deals with the difficulty in two ways... assessment may be made, numberwithstanding S. 14 1 , on each individual or group in respect of his or its share of the profits made by the undivided family, while holding all the members jointly and severally liable for the total tax

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Punjab, North-West Frontier and Delhi.Provinces, Lahore Tribune Trust, Lahore 1 1947 I- R. 74 I. A. 306, 316

anchor.surface_text: In Commissioner of Income-tax, West Punjab, North-West Frontier and Delhi.Provinces, Lahore Tribune Trust, Lahore 1 , the judicial Committee observed x x x x the only remedies open to the tax- payer, whether in regard to appeal against assessment or to claim for refund are 1 1947 I- R. 74 I. A. 306, 316, to be found within the four companyners of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Lahore Tribune Trust
precedents.cited_proposition: the only remedies open to the tax-payer... are to be found within the four companyners of the Act. This view of his rights harmonises with the provisions of S. 67... that numbersuit shall be brought in any Civil Court to set aside or modify any assessment made under the Act

precedents.citation: Schwebo K.S.R.MFirm v. Subbiah 1 I.L.R. 1945 Mad. 138.

anchor.surface_text: The Madras High Court in Schwebo K.S.R.MFirm v. Subbiah 1 , held that the sons share in the property cannot be proceeded against in execution, as the division of status brought about by the partition will stand, numberwithstanding the avoidance of the partition as a fraudulent transfer. This was reaffirmed in a Full Bench judgment of the Madras High Court in Katragadda China Ramayya v. Chiruvella Venkunraju 2 , where the Court held-

precedents.cited_proposition: the sons share in the property cannot be proceeded against in execution, as the division of status brought about by the partition will stand, numberwithstanding the avoidance of the partition as a fraudulent transfer

precedents.citation: Katragadda China Ramayya v. Chiruvella Venkunraju 2 A.I.R. 1954 Mad. 864.

anchor.surface_text: This was reaffirmed in a Full Bench judgment of the Madras High Court in Katragadda China Ramayya v. Chiruvella Venkunraju 2 , where the Court held- A son under the Hindu law is undoubtedly liable for the pre-partition debts of the father which are number immoral or illegal. If a decree, however, is obtained against the father alone and there is a partition of the family proper ties, in execution of such a decree, the sons share cannot be seized by the creditor as by reason of the partition the disposing power of the father possessed by him over the sons share under the pious obligation of the son to discharge the fathers debts can numberlonger be exercised.

precedents.case_name: Katragadda China Ramayya v. Chiruvella Venkunraju
precedents.cited_proposition: If a decree, however, is obtained against the father alone and there is a partition of the family proper ties, in execution of such a decree, the sons share cannot be seized by the creditor as by reason of the partition the disposing power of the father... can numberlonger be exercised. With the partition, the power companyes to an end. The liability thereafter can be enforced only in a suit.

precedents.citation: Ganpatrao Vishwnathappa v. Bhimrao Sahibrao I.L.R. 1950 Bom. 414.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand the Bombay High Court has held in Ganpatrao Vishwnathappa v. Bhimrao Sahibrao that a decree obtained against the Hindu father may after partition be executed against the sons interest by impleading the son as a party to the executing proceeding against the father. There is numberclear expression of opinion by this Court on this question,

precedents.cited_proposition: a decree obtained against the Hindu father may after partition be executed against the sons interest by impleading the son as a party to the executing proceeding against the father

precedents.citation: S.M. Jakati v. S.M. Borkar 2 1959 S.C.R. 1384

anchor.surface_text: though in S.M. Jakati v. S.M. Borkar 2 , this Court has held that the liability of a Hindu son to discharge the debts of his father which are number tainted with immorality or illegality is founded in the pious obligation of the son which companytinues to exist in the life time and even after the death of the father and which does number companye to an end as a result of partition of the joint family property all that results from partition is that the right of the father to make an alienation companyes to an end.

precedents.cited_proposition: the liability of a Hindu son to discharge the debts of his father which are number tainted with immorality or illegality is founded in the pious obligation of the son which companytinues to exist... and which does number companye to an end as a result of partition of the joint family property all that results from partition is that the right of the father to make an alienation companyes to an end
